CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph:

1. PBDT-TDPP-S: This is mentioned several times in the paragraph as the conjugated polymer used in the study.
2. PC71BM: This is mentioned as the blend film used in the study, which is a donor polymer.
3. MoO3: This is mentioned as a layer used in the device structure.
4. Al: This is mentioned as a layer used in the device structure.
5. ITO: This is mentioned as a layer used in the device structure.
6. PEDOT: This is mentioned as a layer used in the device structure.
7. active layer: This is mentioned as the layer between the ITO and MoO3 layers, which is the layer where the conjugated polymer PBDT-TDPP-S is deposited.

So, the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph are:

1. PBDT-TDPP-S
2. PC71BM
3. MoO3
4. Al
5. ITO
6. PEDOT
7. active layer
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Of course! Here are the entities in the paragraph that refer to "Material Name":

1. PBDT-TDPP-S
2. PC71BM

These are the only entities in the paragraph that refer directly to "Material Name".

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Certainly! Here are the valid entities in the paragraph that refer to "Material Name", presented in a Markdown table with one column titled "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PBDT-TDPP-S |
| PC71BM |

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

1. Materials mentioned in the paragraph are:
 * PBDT-TDPP-S

 * ITO
 * PEDOT:PSS (40 nm)
 * Active layer (varied thickness)
2. Property names of the materials:

  + Mobility (hole and electron)
  + FF (fill factor)
 * PC71BM:
  + Mobility (hole and electron)

  + Thickness

  + Thickness

  + Thickness
 * PEDOT:PSS (40 nm):
  + Thickness
 * Active layer (varied thickness):
  + Mobility (hole and electron)
  + Surface roughness
3. The property names of the materials are mentioned in the context of the paragraph as follows:
 * Mobility: 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 (hole mobility) and 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 (electron mobility)
 * FF: listed in Table 4
 * Surface roughness: 0.773 nm (unannealed) and 0.602 nm (annealed)

Note: The property names are mentioned in the context of the paragraph, and the values are provided in the form of citations to the relevant tables or figures.

Of course! Here are the relevant entities that refer to the property name of materials in the paragraph:

6. PEDOT:PSS (40 nm)

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

1. J-V (a) characteristic:
 * J: current density (A/cm^2)
 * V: voltage (V)
 * Values: 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
2. J1/2-V characteristic:
 * J1/2: current density at 1/2 V (A/cm^2)
 * V: voltage (V)
 * Values: 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
3. Table 4:
 * Values: hole mobility (10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1), electron mobility (10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1)
4. Surface roughness:
 * Values: 0.773 nm (unannealed), 0.602 nm (annealed)

So, the values of material properties in the paragraph are:

J-V (a): 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
J1/2-V: 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
Table 4: 3.78 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 (hole mobility), 4.4 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 (electron mobility)
Surface roughness: 0.773 nm (unannealed), 0.602 nm (annealed)
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

Sure, here are the relevant entities and their values for the material properties in the paragraph:

1. Hole mobility:
 * Value: 3.8 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
2. Electron mobility:
 * Value: 4.4 x 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
3. Surface roughness:
 * Value: 0.602 nm (annealed)
